Now as to your actual claim about the Qur‚Äôan, you are simply incorrect. First of all, the word ‚ÄúfasƒÅd‚Äù in Arabic (ŸÅÿ≥ÿßÿØ) literally means _‚Äùa state of disorder, destruction, annihilation, consumption, waste, or ruin‚Äù (Lane‚Äôs Arabic Lexicon)_ It is the exact same word the Qur‚Äôan uses to describe how the universe would ‚Äúbe destroyed‚Äù or ‚Äúfall into utter chaos & ruin‚Äù if there were actually more than one god (thus why monotheism makes sense).

So in context of Qur‚Äôan 5:32 (the passage at hand), it clearly refers to violence, evil, destruction or terror that might not ‚Äútake a life‚Äù per say, as the preceding phrase mentions, but nevertheless would be deserving of capital punishment (and hence the exceptions made). In other words, the Qur‚Äôan here is saying that all life is sacred and off-limits from taking‚Äîbut to remove any ambiguity or confusion (since it also teaches equal justice & not pacifism), the two qualifications are made‚Äînamely that if someone murders, you may justifiably take their life as you would in any governed society & court; and likewise, if they spread violence & chaos such as highway robbery, r***, torture, war-mongering, etc.‚Äîeven if such things may not end any lives per day, they can still be punished with capital penalty, and not incur the massive sin that is being outlined for those who ‚Äútake an innocent life.‚Äù

So it certainly has nothing to do with mere ‚Äúsinning‚Äù or ‚Äúindecency.‚Äù In fact, that is why you seem to have missed that the phrase in the original text is precisely worded as *‚Äùthose who do ‚ÄòfasƒÅd‚Äô ON EARTH‚Äù* which is specifying that this is large-scale crime against humanity or society, which harms and damages the entire land, rather than just being a personal or ‚Äòlocalized‚Äô sin such as mere ‚Äòindecency‚Äô (which has its own unique words in Arabic).

Moreover, this is further solidified by examining other examples of the word ‚ÄòfasƒÅd‚Äô in this formula throughout the Qur‚Äôan. Early on in just the second chapter of the Qur‚Äôan, we already have a CLEAR description (arguably even a definition) of the word ‚ÄúfasƒÅd‚Äù in the following verse, which clearly has to do with spreading physical chaos & violence, rather than mere ‚Äúindecency‚Äù or small-scale wrongs:

*‚ÄùWhen such a person gains power, he strives to spread corruption (fasƒÅd) on earth **_[note the exact same epithet here as S≈´rah_** **5:32**]‚Äî *BY DESTROYING PROPERTIES AND LIVES.* But God does not like violence & chaos [fasƒÅd]!‚Äù _(Qur‚Äôan 2:205)_

There you have it‚Äîclear as day. The word ‚Äúinnocent‚Äù in my earlier translation above was actually just my own summary of those two qualifications of Qur‚Äôan for taking life (namely murder & violence), which I merely condensed into ‚Äúinnocence‚Äù for the sake of ease & summarization. So I didn‚Äôt ‚Äúmiss‚Äù anything. Though I‚Äôm afraid you did. But no worries. I appreciate that you gave me the chance to clarify this point.

*P.S.* It‚Äôs notable to mention that this passage (Qur‚Äôan 5:32) starts by actually stating that this Law (the sanctity of life) was actually originally revealed by God to the Children of Israel (and being re-established here), as an eternal lesson taught to humanity from the Cain & Abel story (which had just been narrated by the Qur‚Äôan in the immediately preceding passage)‚Äîand what‚Äôs interesting is that there has actually a debate raging debating among the scholarly Jewish community as to the actual original rendering of the Talmudic/Rabbinic maxim that states this sanctity of life.

Some Jewish versions have it: *‚ÄùWhoever destroys a single life IN ISRAEL is considered by Scripture to have destroyed the whole world‚Äù*

‚Ä¶While others omit the ‚Äúin Israel‚Äù and leave it open & generic. Well among others, a Jewish believer & writer of the famous Jewish column _‚ÄùPhilologos‚Äù_ (now _‚ÄôMosaic‚Äô)_ actually argues that the Qur‚Äôan PRESERVES the original rendering, which is a generic, open-ended, unrestricted & universal condemnation of taking of life, that is not bound by faith, culture, ethnicity, or national ties. So even Jewish people (the original audience of this moral lesson) are interestingly relying on sources like the Qur‚Äôan itself to support their belief in the universalism of this divine injunction. Just thought I would point that out for what it‚Äôs worth.

Peace.

replies.text:
‚Äã@celestialknight2339 ‚Äã @CelestialKnight23  
Sure, I agree that he broke a fundamental religious rule. I'm just saying that the religious motivation of sin leading to corruption and thus needing to extinguish the source of that sin is the main problem here that shouldn't be ignored in any context.

This exception of capital punishment which you mention renders the point null, though, especially for people like apostates or adulterers etc.? That in itself disproves the sanctity of life.

 ‚ÄúWaging war against Allah and His Messenger‚Äù does not only mean those who bear arms and attack Muslims. In common Islamic terms, this also stands for those who oppose and ideologically fight Islam. Ibn Kathir on 5:33 says: 

‚Äú‚ÄòWage war‚Äô mentioned here means; oppose and contradict, and it includes; disbelief, blocking roads, and spreading fear in the fairways‚Äù.

The second reason given is ‚Äúcorruption‚Äù, which is essentially ‚Äúspreading Islamically unlawful acts in the land‚Äù. 

Meaning doing everything that is outlawed in Islam. Ibn Kathir on 5:33 says ‚ÄúMischief in the land refers to various types of evil‚Äù. 

And I mean, yeah 5:32 isn‚Äôt to tell Muslims killing someone is like killing all humankind, what it does is assert that God told the Israelites that this was a rule and they became transgressors after.

Fasad, in an Islamic context, can refer to spreading corruption on Earth or spreading mischief in a Muslim land, moral corruption against God, or disturbance of the public peace.

Classical Quranic commentators commonly interpreted "corruption in the land" as open disobedience against God or its result. In certain contexts, classical jurists took it to refer to the legal category of Hirabah, comprising armed assault, rape and murder. Some contemporary Muslims view destruction of the natural environment to be among the central meanings of verses referring to fasad.

All of the above can subsequently be true. They're not mutually exclusive. And that isn't even to say all Muslims believe such things, obviously you and many others do not. But to act like these teachings don't have any sort of material harm is wishful thinking.

author: @LisaOfTroy
text: One of the things that always bothered me (and there are many) about the Hae Min Lee Murder is Hae's own words.  For example, in one of the trials, there were two different people where Adnan was going around boasting that Hae wanted to get back together with him.  However, he didn't know at the time that Hae wrote in her diary either on the day of her murder or the day before how much she loved her new boyfriend and thought he was her soulmate.  Adnan made those claims because he knew Hae wouldn't be back to dispute his lies.  Adnan has had many, many different stories over time.  First, he tells police that he asked for a ride and then was busy so he never showed.  Then, he said that he was working on his car in the school parking lot with a friend.  Then, he says he was actually with Jay Wilds but was also at the mosque with 80 people who won't testify for him.  This is speculation, but I suspect when Adnan called Hae with his phone number, she told him that she was on the phone with her new boyfriend and had to go.  This probably enraged Adnan, he gave her one last option to change her mind about him, and he decided to go ahead with his plan.

text:
24:34

The ping on those two outgoing calls show they are from different facings of the tower (denoted by the letters at the end). This fact is used by some of the innocent people to undermine the reliability of the call data. They will also point to some of the Adnan pings being too far apart in distance for time elapsed between them. That is if they don't outright deny that any meaningful deduction can be construed from any cell tower data of that time, due to what they claim about" unpredictability" of tower connections.

Not convinced personally, but just thought I'd present some of their attempts at countering the data.

replies.author: @Riri-ho7pm
replies.text: ‚Äã@laurendal1588 Stephanie received the gift on the day of her birthday because she said to the investigators that she CLEARYLY remembers talking about Adnan's gift with Hae and another girlfriend over their lunch break when asked to confirm if Hae is present at school that day, Januray 13, the day Hae Min went missing which was also happened to be Stephanie's birthday. Try to go over the actual timeline/chronology of that day and read the legal documents as well as Hae's diary and the breakup letter with less bias. Try thinking a girl family memebr or friend of yours was killed and you all just want to find justice for her murder. Just for once, try not to focus on the narrative that somehow everything and everyone went out of their way to frame and point to the ex-bf because of his religion. Based from Hae's diary and all their friends, the breakup only happened in Mid-December which is fairly fresh and only few weeks prior to Jan. 13, Adnan have motive plus, ask yourself when did he wrote the the 'I will kill' note on their initial breakup letter? Why did his phone pinged for an outgoing call near the burial site when he said at the time he was at the mosque? Adnan said he lent his car to Jay bcos he is hanging out with him to kind of remind him to buy Stephanie, Jay's girlfriend, a gift, if that is so, where is this gift, when did Jay got the gift and gave it to his gf?

replies.author: @laurendal1588
replies.text: @Riri-ho7pm not to make you look foolish, but the OP was referring to JAY‚ÄôS gift to Stephanie. Not ADNAN‚ÄôS. That‚Äôs why he says ‚Äúbogus bday gift‚Äù because he doesn‚Äôt believe Adnan lent his car to Jay for the purpose of buying Stephanie a birthday present. And yes, according to both Stephanie she received the gift the next day on the 14th despite Jay telling investigators he asked Jenn to take him to see Stephanie right away when she picked him up from Westview Mall after the burial. And according to both Stephanie and Jay it was jewellery. A ring and a bracelet.

replies.author: @Riri-ho7pm
replies.text: @laurendal1588 Sorry, I assume your statement refers to the gift Stephanie received from Adnan as Adnan and Sarah discussed it in the excerpt of Serial podcast clipped into this video. I never heard or read before that Jay was actually able to get gifts and give it to Stephanie. Thank you for replying and sorry again for my confusion. I wonder what else they shopped that day, if they actually even went to the mall that day because there was a flower boquet paper with Adnan's fingerprints inside Hae's car and Hae has been dating Don at the time, she wouldn't likely to keep old flowers from Adnan where her new beau can see it, would she?

replies.author: @laurendal1588
replies.text: @Riri-ho7pm That‚Äôs ok. No need to apologise. Yes, according to her police notes, Stephanie does indeed receive her birthday gifts from Jay albeit the day after her birthday. There‚Äôs a 14K gold bracelet and gold plated ring with a pink stone. Even though she mentions Jay did see her on the day of her birthday, it was some time after 11pm and he didn‚Äôt give her the gifts then. And this is despite him claiming he asked Jenn to take him straight to his girlfriend because he was so worried about her safety, when Jenn picked him up at 8pm from Westview Mall/or his home. As for the trips to the mall, Jay said he and Adnan went to the mall together before taking him back to school. Adnan says they didn‚Äôt. Interestingly, Jay also says he went to a mall a second time with Mark Pusateri, Jenn‚Äôs younger brother. Finally, as for the flowers in Hae‚Äôs car, it‚Äôs very hard to say when she received them and if she even received them from Adnan at all. If we‚Äôre to go by the State‚Äôs timeline, it would be hard to imagine Adnan being able to get the flowers between last bell at 2:15 and the CAGM call at 2:36. That would mean Adnan would have had to be walking around school with a bouquet of flowers but no one says anything like that.

replies.author: @Riri-ho7pm
replies.text:
‚Äã@laurendal1588 Thank you! Very good points. I was thinking he could have bought the flowers during his vacant time when he was with Jay at the mall then, just hid it in his bag or locker during his last class.

Saw a news article recently saying, one of the DNA matches a man related to Adnan to which many say could be Bilal. I think Bilal may be guilty but only as accessory to the murder because the crime could have been easily done by two people and Adnan would not have to recruit the "pathetic" Jay in the first place. The fact that Jay possessed information that could only be known to those involved directly to the murder such as the location of Hae's car and position Hae's body upon burial means that even if Bilal have motive, he could not have worked alone. The fact that Adnan was seen with Jay mutliple times that day could only mean either it's Adnan-Jay or all three of them in on the plan. Among Adnan, Jay, and Bilal, we know who has the easist opportunity to get close to Hae, isolate her then, strangle her to death without much signs of physical struggle inside the car and all within that short window of time between the end of her class at 2:15PM and her appointment to pick-up her cousin at 3:30PM. I don't understand how people could be so¬†conviced that Adnan is innocent when he has strong motive, weak ambigious alibis that no one can corroborate, an¬†accomplice confessed with first-hand guilt knowledge. It was the tower pings on top everything else that sealed his conviction for me. How about you? What do you think about this case?
